questions.question_text:
An Amazon API Gateway API invokes an AWS Lambda function that needs to interact with a software-as-a-service (SaaS) platform. A unique client token is generated in the SaaS platform to grant access to the Lambda function. A security engineer needs to design a solution to encrypt the access token at rest and pass the token to the Lambda function at runtime.

Which solution will meet these requirements MOST cost-effectively?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C - ParameterStore with SecureString is free.

If the question asking more secure I will prefer SecretManager (which is not in the case)

Selected Answer: C
SecureString is FREE

choices.A: Store the client token as a secret in AWS Secrets Manager. Use the AWS SDK to retrieve the secret in the Lambda function.
choices.B: Configure a token-based Lambda authorizer in API Gateway.
choices.C: Store the client token as a SecureString parameter in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Use the AWS SDK to retrieve the value of the SecureString parameter in the Lambda function.
choices.D: Use AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) to encrypt the client token. Pass the token to the Lambda function at runtime through an environment variable.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It could be A or C - but what makes me thing A is the origin response and this scenario is covered here: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/networking-and-content-delivery/adding-http-security-headers-using-lambdaedge-and-amazon-cloudfront/

Selected Answer: A
The best solution to meet the requirement of adding the X-Frame-Options HTTP header to the responses is:

A. Create a Lambda@Edge function. Include code to add the X-Frame-Options header to the response. Configure the function to run in response to the CloudFront origin response event.

This approach ensures that the header is added to all responses, regardless of the origin (EC2 or S3), and it does not require changes to the application code or the CloudFront distribution settings

questions.question_text:
A company is using an Amazon CloudFront distribution to deliver content from two origins. One origin is a dynamic application that is hosted on Amazon EC2 instances. The other origin is an Amazon S3 bucket for static assets.

A security analysis shows that HTTPS responses from the application do not comply with a security requirement to provide an X-Frame-Options HTTP header to prevent frame-related cross-site scripting attacks. A security engineer must make the full stack compliant by adding the missing HTTP header to the responses.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

choices.B: Create a Lambda@Edge function. Include code to add the X-Frame-Options header to the response. Configure the function to run in response to the CloudFront viewer request event.
choices.D: Customize the EC2 hosted application to add the X-Frame-Options header to the responses that are returned to CloudFront.
choices.A: Create a Lambda@Edge function. Include code to add the X-Frame-Options header to the response. Configure the function to run in response to the CloudFront origin response event.
choices.C: Update the CloudFront distribution by adding X-Frame-Options to custom headers in the origin settings.

questions.question_text:
An application has been built with Amazon EC2 instances that retrieve messages from Amazon SQS. Recently, IAM changes were made and the instances can no longer retrieve messages.

What actions should be taken to troubleshoot the issue while maintaining least privilege? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
B and E sounds right

Selected Answer: BE
To troubleshoot the issue while maintaining least privilege, you should:

B. Verify that the SQS resource policy does not explicitly deny access to the role used by the instances.
E. Verify that the role attached to the instances contains policies that allow access to the queue.

These steps ensure that the IAM policies and resource policies are correctly configured without granting excessive permissions.

choices.B: Verify that the SQS resource policy does not explicitly deny access to the role used by the instances.
choices.D: Attach the AmazonSQSFullAccess managed policy to the role used by the instances.
choices.C: Verify that the access key attached to the role used by the instances is active.
choices.E: Verify that the role attached to the instances contains policies that allow access to the queue.
choices.A: Configure and assign an MFA device to the role used by the instances.

questions.question_text:
A company has an AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer managed key with imported key material. Company policy requires all encryption keys to be rotated every year.

What should a security engineer do to meet this requirement for this customer managed key?

choices.A: Enable automatic key rotation annually for the existing customer managed key.
choices.D: Create a new customer managed key. Import new key material to the new key. Point the key alias to the new key.
choices.C: Import new key material to the existing customer managed key. Manually rotate the key.
choices.B: Use the AWS CLI to create an AWS Lambda function to rotate the existing customer managed key annually.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D.
- you cannot enable automatic key rotation for a KMS key with imported key material
- You can reimport the same key material, but you cannot import different key material into that KMS key
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/importing-keys-considerations.html

comments.content:
Option C (Import new key material to the existing customer managed key. Manually rotate the key) is not suitable because AWS KMS does not support re-importing key material into an existing key. Once key material is imported into a KMS key, it cannot be changed or re-imported.

Therefore, the correct approach is to create a new customer managed key, import the new key material into this new key, and then update the key alias to point to the new key (Option D).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The correct approach to meet the requirement of rotating the encryption key annually for a customer managed key with imported key material is:

D. Create a new customer managed key. Import new key material to the new key. Point the key alias to the new key.

Automatic key rotation is not supported for keys with imported key material. Therefore, you need to manually manage the rotation by creating a new key and updating the alias to point to the new key each year.

kms cmk = metadata (id, other field) + imported material (crypto)
thus kms cmk can continue to be as is with the same id, and we can import new material to it

questions.question_text:
A healthcare company has multiple AWS accounts in an organization in AWS Organizations. The company uses Amazon S3 buckets to store sensitive information of patients. The company needs to restrict users from deleting any S3 bucket across the organization.

What is the MOST scalable solution that meets these requirements?

choices.A: Permissions boundaries in AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
All other solutions are specific to an account and has to be maintained. Considering this D - SCP is the correct answer as it can be set at Organization level.
